description: PRTG Device Template for Bosch Rexroth ctrlX OS devices
author: Darshil Moradiya

description: With this device template, you can monitor the status of your Brocade Fibre Channel switches.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your GarrettCom switches.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Ruckus Wireless devices that use the Ruckus MIB files (RUCKUS--MIB, RUCKUS-ZD--MIB).
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Generic Fibre Channel devices that use the Generic FC-MGMT-MIB (MIBII) 1.3.6.1.3.94.*.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your FortiGate firewalls and FortiSwitch switches.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your ADTRAN routers and switches that use the ADTRAN Operating System (AOS).
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor a Cisco Wireless LAN that is managed by a WLC appliance.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Check Point Next Generation Firewalls (NGFW).
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor devices that use an LSI (Broadcom) RAID controller card via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor Dell storage systems that use the DELL-STORAGE-SC-MIB via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Sophos UTM 9 and your Sophos XG firewalls.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Cybernetics iSAN storage devices via SNMP.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the status of your MikroTik RouterBoard routers.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor devices that use the BGP4-MIB (RFC-1657) via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor the Cisco CallManager component of the Cisco Unified Communications system.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the status of your Cisco switch stack units via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Axis network camera via SNMP.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the health of your Juniper switches that are based on Junos OS.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the health, stats and volume of a Nasuni Filer storage device.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Fujitsu Eternus SAN.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor your Palo Alto firewalls via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor energy usage data from a Sonoff Pow R2 smart switch that runs Tasmota firmware.
author: Simon Bell

description: With this device template, you can monitor QNAP NAS systems and QNAP Expansion Units via SNMP.
author: Luciano Lingnau

description: With this device template, you can monitor the status, the volumes, and other device stats of a Hikvision IP network camera.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the access points and the SSID traffic of an HPE Aruba wireless device.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the chassis health of an Brocade Ethernet Switch device. The device template is based on the Foundry MIB.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor the disks and volumes of an HPE Nimble Storage via SNMP.
author: JR Andreassen

description: With this device template, you can monitor a Kemp load balancer.
author: JR Andreassen

display_name: Integrate PRTG with Osirium Privileged Access Management Server
description: This blog article explains how to integrate PRTG with Osirium’s Privileged Access Management Server, via its REST API. The script, and instructions can be found here https://gitlab.com/PRTG/Sensor-Scripts/Osirium-PAM
author: Paessler Script

description: With PRTG, you can monitor RingCentral out of the box with the REST Custom sensor. You can use this sensor, i.e. to monitor the status of RingCentral calls and meetings. The sensor can show the following: Calling inbound/outbound status, Engage voice status, Meetings status, Phones status, and the Service portal status. For an overview see the service status page.

With PRTG, you can monitor Cisco Webex out of the box with the EXE/Script Advanced sensor. You can use this sensor to monitor the status of Webex meetings and Webex calling, for example. Among others, the sensor can show the following: Webex Meetings status, Webex Messenger status, Webex Control Hub status, Webex Teams status, UCM Cloud status

With PRTG, you can monitor the overall status of GoToMeeting, GoToWebinar, GoToTraining, and OpenVoice from LogMeIn out of the box with the REST Custom sensor. You can use this sensor to monitor, for example, the status of your meetings and webinars. The sensor can show the following: GoToMeeting status, GoToWebinar status, GoToTraining status, and OpenVoice status.
With PRTG, you can monitor join.me out of the box with the REST Custom sensor. You can use this sensor to monitor, for example, the overall status of join.me calls and meetings.

This custom Script v2 sensor will monitor SSL certificates that require a protocol handshake prior to reading certificate data, and exposes the collected data in channels similar to PRTG's built-in SSL Certificate sensor. The LDAP protocol handshake has been tested against Active Directory, OpenLDAP, and Sun Enterprise Directory Server and is expected to work with RedHat DS 389 directory server.
author: Andreas Strobl

description: This blog article explains how to integrate Flowmon’s digital performance security suite with PRTG - . It describes how you can use a set of custom sensors to retrieve monitoring data from a Flowmon device. Flowmon have kindly allowed us to share them on our Gitlab site as well. A ZIP archive containing the scripts, and a PDF document containing instructions. Additonal info can be found here.
With this script, you can monitor your Raise3D printer.
With this script, you can back up all vital files of PRTG and show them in a sensor.
author: JR Andreassen

display_name: ReFS (Resilient File System) and Veeam Backups
description: We formatted our backup hard disks with ReFS and set up the new Veeam backup repository. This way, we saved almost 10 terabytes of disk space for our backups. For more information, see the linked blog article.
With this script, you can create a button to pause the PRTG core server.
With this script, you can export PRTG system information for devices.

With this script, you can query the REST API of Mirth (as of version 4.3). This creates the Mirth System Health sensor that provides system values such as CPU load, free memory, and free hard disk space, and the Channel sensor that monitors the number of sent and received messages as well as faulty and buffered messages per channel.
author: Johannes Liegert

description: With this script, you can monitor the PHP-FPM Status page in PRTG. For more information on how to enable this, see Nginx - Enable PHP-FPM Status Page.

With this script, you can monitor the available size (MB/GB/TB and percentage) of the Windows mounts on the target host. The script can also cope with GUID changes of the actual volume because it works with the labels rather than the GUIDs.
author: Stephan Linke

description: With this script, you can check if a URL returns the expected return code and if it does not, you are alerted.

With this script, you can read historic events for a Windows host and filter for various credentials. You can search multiple channels and providers and get custom alerts based on event IDs and strings.

display_name: Get List of Usernames Configured in PRTG
description: With this script, you can get a sortable list of all usernames that are configured on devices and in groups. You can filter the list as required.
With this script, you can check the HTTP response code from a specified website. The script also allows you to configure custom headers if necessary.

display_name: Find Groups and Devices with Enabled Auto-Discovery
description: With this script, you can find all enabled auto-discoveries that are configured in PRTG.
With this script, you can get a sortable list of devices in PRTG that have no configured sensors yet.
With this script, you can query the Active Directory and find users that are, for example, locked or disabled. The resulting users are displayed in the last message field in PRTG.
With this script, you can display the amount of unique users and computers that have shares open, as well as the total amount of share sessions for the specified host.

display_name: SCVMM: Hyper-V Hosts and Virtual Machines
description: With this script, you can monitor your SCVMM and all hosts and VMs that reside on it.

We changed the way PRTG handles notification emails and simplified the approach so that there is only one email notification template and the option to deliver plain text emails. This is sufficient for most users. With this script, users that have multiple email clients can create customized notifications, languages, logos and layouts.
With this script, you can make sure that you do not forget to resume any paused sensors.
With this script, you can monitor if your APC battery needs to be replaced.
With this script, you can monitor a website that is behind a login form. The script uses PowerShell to fill in the form and to perform a string check on the website to which it is redirected.
With this script, you can monitor the table fragmentation rates of a MySQL database server. Note that we also provide an alternative method in the Knowledge Base article.
With this script, you can monitor remote registry databases and do checks on the desired key (mustcontain, mustnotcontain) via string or regex.

display_name: Monitor Users Logged in to PRTG
description: With this script, you can track how many users concurrently use PRTG on a daily basis.
With this script, you can create a sensor with which you can determine the active node in your MSCS (Microsoft Cluster Service).
With this script, you can make sure that all automatic services are up and running.
With this script, you can check the age of the installed signature database of McAfee.

display_name: Get List of Configured Remote Probes
description: With this script, you can get an overview of your remote probe configuration and the corresponding available GUIDs.
With this script, you can monitor the bgpPeerTable on your Cisco appliance.

display_name: Monitor Linux Distributions Incompatible with SSH Disk Free Sensor
description: With this script, you can get disk metrics using an EXE/Script sensor. The sensor connects to the server, executes the specified command, and returns the corresponding disks. Note that you might need to modify the command.
With this script, you can monitor the health of a Google Search Appliance.
With this script, you can check the MySQL database server replication for the specified host. The script checks if the replication was successful and returns the result on an HTTP web page.

display_name: HP ProCurve Switch Version and Model
description: With this script, you can monitor the software version of your ProCurve switches and show the model information in the sensor message. The version is divided into Major, Minor, and Patchlevel. You can set channel limits to find old versions. The recommended scanning interval is 24 hours.
With this script, you can track the number of users in a specific Active Directory group.
With this script, you can monitor your Altaro server backups by checking the corresponding event logs.
With this script, you can monitor a specific Linux service for its availability. If the service is not started, the script automatically tries to start it.

With this script, you can execute SSH commands via PowerShell. This makes PRTG compatible with systems that do not work with the internal SSH client. You can use the script to execute scripts located in /var/prtg/scriptsxml and /var/prtg/scripts, or simply as a notification that executes commands on Linux hosts, if required.

PRTG offers a native Traceroute Hop Count sensor that has, however, a static channel architecture so that it is not feasible to create a sensor with one channel for each hop. With this script, you can monitor the IP addresses of hops and show the route in the sensor message.

display_name: Workaround for Scripts Running Longer than 900 Seconds
description: If your scripts take a very long time to be executed, they might timeout in PRTG because 15 minutes is the longest time span that PRTG waits for results. With this script, we provide a workaround for scripts that run longer than these 15 minutes.

With this script, you can find out which objects (if any) have enabled SNMP debugging. Note that if you enabled SNMP debugging for a support request, for example, and forgot to turn it off, this can fill up your hard drive rather quickly.
With this script, you can monitor processes that change their name frequently, for example, depending on the amount of spawned processes.

Monitors Veeam Backup & Replication jobs. Includes last backup status, time to next backup, how long backup has been running for and the time since the last backup. Custom status message shows pertinent data based on the current state of the job. Custom lookup enhances the Backup State channel to identify the state of the last backup.
author: LordMilko

display_name: Script Sensors for Rhebo Industrial Protector
description: This blog article explains how to integrate Rhebo’s Industrial Protector software with PRTG & describes how to use a set of custom sensors to retrieve monitoring data from the Rhebo system. The script sensors mentioned are available on our Gitlab site. 2 files are included: ZIP archive containing the scripts, and READ.md text file provides additional info about the scripts and how to use them.
A PowerShell script that connects to the Cortex XDR REST API, reads incident statuses, and creates a custom sensor for PRTG.
author: Daniel Weber

description: Monitors Aruba CX Switches using the Switch Rest API
author: Jannos-443

description: PRTG powershell script to monitor Proxmox VE (PVE)
author: Jannos-443

description: This code is for an ESP2866 and monitors your PRTG server for errors and warnings. Depending on status of PRTG it will color an IKEA pencil green, yellow or red.This project was created to give our helpdesk a visual aid for the status of PRTG. Inside of pencil has been replaced by LED ring and a small ESP2866. A WiFi antenna has been placed on the outside of the pencil for better (internet) range.
author: bduijnhouwer

description: This script is designed to be used as a PRTG custom sensor to monitor FlexLM license usage. It parses license usage logs and reports the number of currently checked-out licenses for various products, providing multiple channels for monitoring each product.
author: gitnol

description: PRTG Sensor script to monitor a certificate revocation list (CRL)
author: Jannos-443

description: Integrates the JobRouter Admin Overview into PRTG Monitoring, leveraging a PHP script to extract relevant information directly from the JobRouter Database.While it's possible to use the SQL queries provided in the codebase with PRTG's SQL sensors, this implementation operates via HTTP. Makes it especially useful in cloud environments where direct database access might be restricted or undesirable.
author: Daniel Winkels

description: Retrieve the status information of a registered scheduled task in windows and return the results in Json format
author: Markus

description: Python script for monitoring Qumulo Quotas in PRTG.
author: Leandro Boccia

description: Check if a HDD need to be defragmented and exclude SSDs.
author: Clement

description: Preexisting SNMPs don't work with our Ice Qube AC boxes. The code I have made will parse the temperature data (presented as a string data-type) of the entered IP address that the Ice Qube is assigned. The threshold can be changed by the user.
author: Evan Tolan

description: A python script to call PRTG's API and create a CSV file with the uptime and downtime stats for sensors with a specific tag.
author: Greg Campion

description: Powershell Script to monitor Citrix Netscaler (ADC). High Availability, System, CertExpiration, Interface, vServer, vServerHealth.
author: Jannos-443

description: This custom Python Script Advanced sensor will monitor SSL certificates that require a protocol handshake prior to reading certificate data, and exposes the collected certificate data in channels similar to PRTG's built-in SSL Certificate sensor. Supported protocols with STARTTLS to secure the connection: SMTP, LMTP, LDAP.
author: astrobl1904

description: PRTG Powershell Script to monitor Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager
author: Jannos-443

description: Monitor Office365 & Azure audit logs for the presence of certain logs or log values through an Advanced .exe sensor. Examples are monitoring for failed Azure AD logins, spoofing prevention in Exchange online, DLP alerts, deletion of import files on Sharepoint, etc. Anything that comes in an audit log can be made into a PRTG sensor channel. See Github page for onboarding instructions.
author: Daan de Boer

display_name: Python Class Library for PRTG API
description: This is a class library that can be used to populate a 'server' object with all child devices and respective child sensors. Can retrieve text status, tags, search by tags, start and stop sensors.
author: Timothy Quan

description: This Advanced Sensor will monitor and report Internet speed using Ookla, SpeedTest.net.
author: jaroslavmraz

description: PRTG Powershell Script to monitor Citrix ADC. System Status, HA Status and other metrics
author: Jannos-443

description: This script outputs a Upload and Download Measurment of Iperf3. This has been tested and developed against Iperf 3.0.11 at the time of submission.
author: Leopold Strobl

description: Custom EXE/XML script for PRTG to monitor Ubiquiti WiFi access points with data from Unifi controller. Greater amount of values available, than MIBs from Ubiquiti. Detailed info in the status message, such as SSID, uplink switch and port number (if using Ubiquiti switches). Pre-set errors and warnings for poor WiFi experience. Caching of API results so infrastructures with a lot of access points.
author: Angela-D

description: PRTG Powershell Script to monitor CrowdStrike
author: Jannos-443

description: This blog article explains how PRTG can be used to check the status of clients that are protected by Acronis’ MSP focussed Cyber Protect Cloud - The sensors and detailed instructions can be found here: https://solutions.acronis.com/en-us/integrations/paessler-prtg

One sensor to monitor all LACP port channels on Cisco Catalyst switches. Will show the following states. Ok: All ports in LACP Port-Channel up & bundled in port-channel. Error: All ports in Port-channel in Individual or down state (can be notconnected or suspend). Warning: If some ports in port-channel in Individual state or down. Warning: If Port-channel interface administratively down.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: Script looking for available updates of packages installed on your Synology NAS and showing a warning in PRTG
author: Ingo Asche

description: Take use of Cloudflare API to monitor status of your Argo tunnels.
author: Nikolai

description: PRTG Monitoring script for Checkpoint VPN Certificates expiration. Sensor creates channels for every VPN Certificate. Warning limit 14 days. Error limit 7 days.
author: Jeroen Deckers

description: AOVPN Connection Statistics monitoring.
author: Gillian van der Kwaak

display_name: Microsoft Azure VHD Host Pool Status
description: PowerShell script which can be used to display the AVD Host Pool status or create a PRTG sensor. It measures: number of active sessions how many hosts is available what is the current session limit what is the current session usage (%)
author: Kristof Kuderko

display_name: Integrate PRTG with Fastvue Syslog Server
description: This blog article explains how to integrate PRTG with Fastvue’s freeware Syslog Server, via its REST API - How to get the most out of Syslog monitoring with PRTG and Fastvue

Custom NVIDIA GPU sensor is written in Python and uses the PRTG "Python Advanced Script" or "HTTP Push Data Advanced" sensor to collect NVIDIA GPU telemetry data. Collects GPU Performance State, Temperature, Utilization, Memory Utilization, Total Memory, Used Memory, Free Memory metrics.
author: Richard Bocchinfuso

description: This sensor will monitor your Cisco ASA HA pair, and let you know which ASA is in which status for the pair.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: Using VMWare PowerCLI this Script checks VMware VM Disk Latency
author: Jannos-443

description: This Script can monitor DataCore.
author: Jannos-443

description: Scripts to enable using Let's Encrypt certificates with PRTG. Currently, Certify the Web can use this project's post-install script to update PRTG's SSL Certificate.
author: AndyZib

description: Turn custom sensor scripts into HTTP Push sensors. The scripts themselves are not sensors; they are interfaces for using existing (non-push) sensor scripts as push sensors and creating new push sensors.
author: Evan Linde

description: Monitor one or more systemd units with PRTG. Set an OK status for units that are active or an Error status for units that are not active. The units monitored can be services, any other unit type, or any combination of unit types.
author: Evan Linde

description: This custom PRTG sensor can be used to monitor the status of enabled Microsoft SQL Server agent jobs. It ensures that the status of every job is available and that failed jobs impose a sensor failure.
author: Leonard de Ruijter

description: This guide will show you how to use the nVidia-SMI for gathering metrics on nVidia's business line of GPUs. Including, Tesla, GRID, Quadro and Titan X products, though limited support is also available on other NVIDIA GPUs.
author: Stefan Zuban

description: Using VMware PowerCLI this Script checks disk space of every VM.
author: Jannos-443

description: Keep track of how long until your domains expire.
author: Jordan Burch

description: Powershell script that links to twillio api sending a basic text message using the Execute Program settings under notifications
author: Jordan Burch

description: Monitors Windows Eventlog. Excludes and includes possible.
author: Jannos-443

description: This sensor modified and work with switch which do not provide SFP DDM information by SNMP (For example Cisco 3850 with new software version) It gets data from SSH. Signal level and thresholds then compare level with thresholds established by the device.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: This is multichannel sensor each channel represent BGP neighbor status.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: This is multichannel sensor. Each channel represent EIGRP neighbor status, and neighbors count in each AS
author: Oleg Volkov

display_name: Notification Script for PagerDuty Event API 2
description: A Simple PowerShell based "Execute Program" notification for PRTG that uses PagerDuty's Event API v2 This KB article explains how to configure the notification to send alerts to PagerDuty, using their Events API v2:
author: Simon Bell

description: Checks SQL database size, space available and used space for every database!
author: Jannos-443

description: Using WinRM and WMI this script counts logged on users. You can exclude users or include only one or two users.
author: Jannos-443

description: Bash script for PRTG by Paessler to monitoring status of remote snashot replication. The sensor will show the status and time passed since the last replication. The data is collected from /var/log/synolog/synodr.log. Sensor has to be created in PRTG on your Synology device. Sensor tested on DS 918+ with DSM 6.2.4-25556.
author: Ingo

description: This script checks MSSQL Backup, Log Backup and Differential Backup Age for all databases
author: Jannos-443

description: This archive contains a sample set of Python Script Sensors for PRTG that will retrieve health and performance data from a unified communications infrastructure that is managed by Telchemy SQMediator.
Using WMI to check MS Cluster Resources, Cluster Disk space, Cluster Nodes and Cluster Interfaces
author: Jannos-443

description: Using VMWare PowerCLI this Script checks VMware Alerts and Warnings
author: Jannos-443

description: This Sensor will allow you to monitor the license usage within your Microsoft 365 environment. You can use the parameter $SKUPattern and parameter $exclude to exclude/include specific SKUs.
author: Jannos-443

description: Using VMWare PowerCLI this Script checks VMware VM Status for example VMware Tools, Heartbeat, CDDrive Connected and Overall State
author: Jannos-443

description: Monitors DHCP Scopes (PercentageInUse, AddressesFree and AddressesInUse) Monitors DHCP Failover State and Mode
author: Jannos-443

description: This script checks if Windows Cluster Roles are on preferred Node(s)
author: Jannos-443

description: Monitors pending Print Jobs older than x minutes. Sensor message shows PrinterQueue and Job Owner.
author: Jannos-443

description: This Sensor Monitors Snapshots with specific Age or Size. Default Values: WarningHours = 24 (hours) ErrorHours = 48 (hours) WarningSize = 10 (GB) ErrorSize = 20 (GB
author: Jannos-443

description: This Sensor will allow you to monitor the failover state of a Cisco ASA appliance. An english manual can also be found in the repository.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: A very simple example of how to make PRTG Network Monitor metrics available to Prometheus. PRTG-Exporter-core uses PrtgAPI to receive the metrics and Prometheus-net to export metrics to Prometheus.
author: Luke-777

description: Monitor number of agents present in a Teams Call Queue, and create a dashboard for call center purpose. Monitors Agent names, optin agents, and optout agents for queues.
author: Benny Giebens

description: With this script, you can monitor how many days are remaining for your Dell device warranty based on the service tag.
author: darkhalo49

description: The purpose of this sensor is to keep a running count of the number of key presses/mouse clicks that a user makes over an amount of time. Ideally, this script will run while a user's PC is online, and will push data constantly until it is turned off. The script will gather this information, and push the statistics of: KeyPresses, MouseClicks, and TotalActionsPerMinute to the PRTG sensor.
author: Jordan Burch

display_name: Cisco APIC CPU CPU and Disk Capacity
description: With PRTG, you can monitor Cisco APIC CPU and disk capacity with the EXE/Script Advanced sensor. Excutes a Golang compiled into EXE File on the PRTG probe system.
author: Max Huang

description: PRTG Script to monitor Smart status of all drives. The script will find all open end devices, and check for smart errors. This is intended to run on Linux systems.
author: Async-IT

description: PRTG Script to monitor ZPool Capacity in %, total size and used size. Script handle Gigabyte and TeraByte capacities.
author: Jonas Sauge

description: Retrieves ans outputs the stats of a go-e HOME+ charger in XML format. Among others, it shows the Currents, Total Power, Voltages, Firmware Versions, Temperatures and many more.
author: Antoine Hauck

description: Bash script for PRTG by Paessler to monitoring status of backup with Synology's Hyper Backup. The Sensor will show the status of the backups and the time passed since the last backup. The data is collected from /var/log/synolog/synobackup.log.
author: Ingo Asche

description: For monitoring SIP peers (SIP phones). Asterisk version lower than 12 do not have REST API but have AMI interface, this sensor utilize AMI.
author: Volkov Oleg

description: Verify each VM on Hyper-v environment to check if there is a delay with one ou more VMs and format the result to PRTG exe Sensor
author: Gustavo Pustai

description: Monitors used capacity of zpools (like rpool or syspool) in your ZFS System, output is in %.
author: Manuel Wolff

description: You can monitor the progress of your user and your friends, if you are not in one team, or your team is too big. Please do not try to monitor more than 10 Usernames, otherwise script will get very slow and PRTG will time-out. Note that there are two different FOH scripts, one for users, one for groups. Make sure to use the corresponding parameters.
author: Manuel Wolff

description: You can monitor the progress of your users and your friends, if you are not in one team or your team is too big. Please do not try to monitor more than 10 usernames, otherwise the script can get very slow and PRTG will time-out.
author: Manuel Wolff

description: An alternative to WMI monitoring method that doesn't require PRTG to have a user account on the target machine or domain admin credentials; with options to auto-start whitelisted services. This script runs on the target machine, rather than the probe device/PRTG and utilizes the PRTG API for sensor alerts.
author: Angela D.

description: AutoMonX has developed a tailor-made Health Reporter for large deployments of PRTG. Now you can get a comprehensive report on the status of your PRTG deployment. Core and probe servers are scanned for their operating system status of Memory, Disk and PRTG services. General monitoring health indicators are also gathered and included in the report.
author: AutoMonX

description: Get PRTG notifications when new / unassigned tickets are detected. The Python script (zendesk_notifier) gets ran on a schedule and checks your Zendesk account for new / unassigned tickets. When a condition is met (new / unassigned tickets), it sends a hook to PRTG and an alert notification gets pushed to your PRTG dashboard.
author: Angela D.

description: Sensor for PRTG monitoring system. For monitoring SIP trunk with registration. Asterisk version lower than 12 do not have REST API but have AMI interface, this sensor utilize AMI.
author: Oleg Volkov

description: Qualys SSL Report Grading for PRTG is a custom PowerShell script that queries the Qualys SSL Labs Service and allows you to grade a (public) web property's SSL Settings.
author: Michel Zehnder

description: A standalone ping sensor w/jitter for PRTG. Includes response time (latency), jitter, and packet loss. The sensor can function as Master sensor for parent.
author: Ivan Rios

description: Using PRTG to monitor Windows services can be done with the integrated services sensor. However, this sensor can only monitor one service at the same time. This can be very useful to track memory or CPU usage of services, but in most cases you simply like to know, if all services are running as inteded. An there is no built-in means for that.
author: Marc Debold

description: With the addition of Citrix to the enterprise-such as with Windows Server 2016-terminal servers, one or the other IT department is forced to monitor how the RDS licenses' utilization is. Because in the long run it is conceivable that one would not even notice if licenses become free again - if one would not check this - even manually - on the RDS license server.
author: Daniel Leeser

display_name: SCCM Sync Status and WMI Module
description: This project has two scripts which can report on the SCCM server's ability to remain synchronized with Microsoft's update catalog, as well as report counts of software update deployment states per deployment.
author: Drew M

description: This PowerShell script allows you to send notifications from within PRTG to a certain Discord Channel.
author: Michael P Metully

description: Simple script to create a sensor for PRTG by Paessler which uses the output of btrfs dev stats to show the health of your Btrfs volume.
author: Ingo Asche

description: This script allows you to get various status information about your NextCloud Instance.
Working OIDlib for Mikrotik CCR series.
author: Stefan Certic

description: The following script was created to bypass an issue in the SOAP API in relation with VMware, hardware vendor drivers and PRTG.
author: Florian Rossmark

description: Bash script for PRTG to monitoring status of device backup in Synology Active Backup for Business.
author: Ingo Asche

description: Custom PRTG Sensor to track the location of a VCSA VM. Useful if it goes down and you need to know the host it's on. Set a notification email up for changes so you have this info sent to you every time it vmotions.
author: Chris Forsey

description: Repository containing the following sensors: .NetFramework Version AAD Group based Licensing AD FSMO AD Global Catalog AD OU Client W10 Branch DHCP Scope Exchange 2013 Version Exchange 2016 Version Exchange 2019 Version
Powershell script to monitor the Status Devices from TeamViewer using PRTG. Script generated using TeamViewerPSModules from PowerShell Studio 2019.
Simple script sensors for PRTG by Paessler to check the health of a Samba Active Directory.
author: Ingo Asche

description: Script for monitoring Joan devices (getjoan.com), supports only on-premise management server. Script does return state, battery level, temperature and wifi signal level of the device within a PRTG custom EXE/XML sensor.
author: Viktor Kalivoda

description: This BASH script allows you to monitor volume information about your Synology NAS via the SSH Custom Advanced Sensor.
author: Ingo Asche

description: This BASH script allows you to monitor share information about your Synology NAS via the SSH Custom Advanced Sensor.
author: Ingo Asche

description: A simple script to monitor an IP address other than the parent's host address. Returns response time in "ms".
author: Clément Juillac

description: This script allows you to monitor the Windows Update Status from any Windows Based Server - no matter if domain joined or not. It sends the data via PRTG's HTTP Push Data Advanced Sensor.
author: Stefan Müller - TS-Management GmbH

description: Utilize static error alerts for custom log behavior with PRTG's webhook API.
author: Angela D

description: AutoMonX Ltd has developed a custom PRTG sensor pack for monitoring Microsoft Azure cloud environments. These unique sensors are utilizing the power of PRTG to monitor the various aspects of Microsoft Azure’s resources and services. The sensor pack currently supports auto-discovery and monitoring of 17 Azure resources (and counting).
author: AutoMonX Ltd

description: This PowerShell Script will invoke a command to a target system and count the files currently in the index. This has to be invoked, though the OLEDB provider of the Search Index allows remote-requests, it does not give you accurate numbers for the overall scope of the index on the system using remote requests.
author: Florian Rossmark

description: This project will read the University of Oxford Status API and digest it into PRTG Network Monitor. This project was created by James Preston of AN Security to demonstrate the usefulness of the REST Custom sensor in PRTG.
author: James Preston

description: Automatically open Zendesk tickets for triggered sensors using Powershell. Forked from Integrating Zendesk and PRTG (https://tietze.io/b/2015/09/08/integrating-zendesk-and-prtg/).
author: Angela

description: This script creates a sensor in PRTG that displays the allocation of physical resources (CPU/RAM) to virtual machines. Also returns the number of virtual machines
author: Romain Drouche

description: If you're using unattended upgrades and have automatic installs running, this script can tell you if you have pending reboot. If you are also automatically rebooting, you can set this up so that you know when a server has not rebooted for longer than a certain amount of time, e.g. 24hrs.
author: Jonas Vacek

description: The supplied sensors can be used to monitor several aspects of a bMS installation through PTRG. These sensors use the bConnect interface to read information from your bConnect installation.
author: baramundi software AG

description: Lists all present snapshots for a given VMware vSphere instance. You can provide how old the snapshots must be to be listed by this script. It shows for each snapshot the associated virtual machine name, name and description and the snapshot's age in days.
author: Antoine Hauck

display_name: Active Directory User Lockout Monitoring Script
description: The following script will read through your current Active Directory and filter for user accounts with the following specific conditions: Lockedout users, disabled users, expired users and users with password never expires set.
This custom sensor monitors different aspects of a Baramundi bConnect instance.
author: Sven Soost

description: This sensor monitors the Dynamic RAM of a Hyper-V Host via PowerShell.
author: Michael Gempp

description: This sensor allows you to monitor the expiration dates of multiple webservers at once.
author: Stefan Müller - TS-Management GmbH

description: This bash script check for new video files on the Unifi Video NVR. Just edit path to video files and time for last recordings and add the SSH sensor within PRTG.

This is an Add-On for Starface PBX, using the built-in Module System. The serverside is designed, to allow other users to create their own channels, there are some demo-modules, i,e.: hdd-space, amount of user licenses left, lines on/offline, and more. The add-on on the PRTG-Monitor's side is a 10kb small client, which only has the task to connect to the PBX, authenticate and get the XML file.
author: Fabian Zünd

description: This script allows you to monitor ClamAV Services on a FreeBSD based System. This script uses the SSH Script Sensor.
author: networksadmin

description: This script allows you to monitor your remaining BulkSMS Credits.

A simple command line application to check the status of one or multiple game servers. Supports single run, continuous check and PRTG XML export As it uses the Gameserverinfo library to check the various game servers.
author: Stefan Bautz (roots84)

description: Advanced Sensor which will Report Statistics about Backups during the last 24 Hours and Actual Repository usage.
author: Markus Kraus

description: Useful for Telnet connections to Cisco Switches and other devices. Customized to return data to PRTG via an EXE/Advanced sensor for a Citrix port 1494 ICA response code
This sensor transforms the output of the device's command "ceph -s" into readable output for PRTG.
author: KBB GmbH

description: PrtgXml provides a declarative syntax for generating the XML output required by EXE/Script Advanced custom sensors.
author: lordmilko

description: PrtgAPI is a C#/PowerShell library that abstracts away the complexity of interfacing with the PRTG HTTP API.
author: lordmilko

description: This sensor provides a good overview of the current operational health of the arrays monitored while ensuring that the reporting was not overly complicated. The sensor covers the following level conditions: Array capacity status, Array performance metrics, General hardware status of Controllers, Shelves and Chassis, General drive health.
author: David Lloyd

description: This script will display the current status of specific DHCP scopes that might fill up from time to time.
This sensor queries all values that the Seatel's DacRemP program can deliver. You can find an extensive explanation in your Knowledgebase under How can I monitor my Seatel DAC/MXP in PRTG?.
author: Fredde87

description: This sensor uses Telnet to retrieve the state of an iDirect modem. It will report RX SNR, TX RefPower, the selected Beam and the TX State (including TX Mute).
author: Fredde87

description: This is an addition to the PRTG web console to display a tab for related tickets to on sensors and device. To use the script just copy js.document from the GitHub page into your PRTG Program Directory. With PRTG version 17.3.34 all UI customizations will disappear with each update. You will have to re-apply any customizations after each update.
author: Jonatan Bernal

description:
Script that uses PRTG's API to check the SLA/Uptime Average of all Sensors on your server.
There is a Daily, Weekly and Since Deployment Mode.
author: evanlanester

description: This script connects to the the Veeam Backup and Replication Server with the VeeamPSSnapin (you must install the Veeam Console on the probe device) and checks the "last result" for all enabled jobs. One channel per Job is returned. No specific edition of Veeam is required. This script was last tested against Veeam Backup and Replication 9.5 Update 2.
author: Philipp Koch

description: Scans the volumes of a NetApp Filer for their oldest snapshot. Each volume is returned as one channel, the value is the age of the oldest snapshot.
author: Philipp Koch

description: The monitoring of the Multi-WAN status is not possible through SNMP on WatchGuard firewall (according to a WatchGuard support case). This script monitors the Mutli-WAN status via the Webinterface of the WatchGuard. This works for cluster or non-clustered.
author: e-i-n-s

description: A collection of PRTG sensor scripts to monitor key NetScaler metrics including health, performance, configuration status, vServer status and certificate expiration.
author: Jason McKenry

description: Script will iterate through all available Exchange mailboxes and return all mailboxes that are bigger than the corresponding trigger limit for that mailbox. The trigger limit results from the defined warning quota for that mailbox minus the provided limit offset (default: 0.2 GB). If no warning quota is defined for a mailbox, the database default quota will be used for that mailbox.
Among other scripts, you'll find custom sensors for monitoring VMWare's Horizon 7. It allows you to monitor sessions, pools and provisioned VMs.
author: pbraxmeier

description: This script will return the difference in minutes between the current date and the last time each VM replicated from Primary to the Replica server.

Monitors reoccurring subscriptions so you know when to pay your bills for third party IT applications. ( obviously can be extended past just IT) Remember no more than 50 channels on this custom sensor.

PowerShell Module For Administrating PRTG It eases the rollout-/deployment process for new machines and management of existing machines with all there sensors. The shipped cmdlets are used to call the PRTG API (http://prtg.paessler.com/api.htm?username=demo&password=demodemo)
This allows you to monitor the age of shadow copies for a given drive on a Windows Server.
Python module for managing PRTG servers. It allows you to browse your sensor tree and manage each group, device, sensor or channel as an object that you can pause, resume, rename, delete, clone etc.
author: hutchris

description: Retrieves the processed mails by MailScanner during the last timespan. The 1st parameter defines the password to access the MailScanner MySQL database. The 2nd parameter defines the timespan in minutes. Wrong or invalid input defaults to 15 minutes.
author: saxos1983

description: This script is called from PRTG to run Pester tests and record the results in PRTG. By default, each channel in the sensor will error if a test fails.
author: Jeremy McGee

description: This script allows you to monitor the time since the last YUM update.

Today telegram launched a new service. Telegram BOT. You can HTTP trigger this bot to send messages / photo etc. At a older article i created a telegram bot with Linux but now its much easyer to do this.
This will allow you to check the queue length of the Linux based mail server EXIM.

This script provided by the renowned Exchange portal MSXFAQ allows you to monitor transaction logs, Database Size EDB, ActiveSync Data as well as active users. There are multiple other linked sensors. Please note that the page is only available in German.
A custom sensor for PRTG to monitor RabbitMQ Queues and Exchanges
This will allow you to monitor multiple Veeam Backup and Replication servers, detailed backup statistics. Alerting is also provided.
This will allow you monitor your Atlantis ILIO environment using PRTGs SNMP Library Sensor.

This script monitors the NetApp SnapMirror relationships via SNMP. Each relationship results in one channel. Channel names are FilerA:volA - FilerB:volB. The message of the sensor is set to the relationship name with the biggest lag time.
author: philipp1993

description: It allows you to monitor currently logged in Windows users using an external EXE provided by PRTGToolsFamily.
You can monitor your Allnet PowerMeter UPS with this.
Monitor active lync users as well as the amount of inbound and outbound calls.
This is a PowerShell module for PRTG that allows managing to a certain extent.

As part of tech. partnership with Paessler, the SAP-based service provider itesys has developed a comprehensive package of SAP sensors for integration into PRTG monitoring tool. The sensors deliver num. values & parameters for IDoc, SAP Jobs, Work Process, Dialog, and many more including SAP databases such as SAP HANA, Oracle, MSSQL or DB2. All sensors can be tested with the free demo license.
author: itesys AG

description: Monitors the free space on disks of a Linux/Unix system via the SNMP.
Monitors the usage of the CPU cores of a system via SNMP.
Connects to a Linux/Unix system via SSH and executes a script file that is located on the target system.
Monitors the system load average of a Linux/Unix system via SNMP.
Monitors the memory usage of a system via SNMP.
Monitors the health of Cisco Meraki network devices via the Cisco Meraki Dashboard API.
Monitors the VPN connections of a Fortinet FortiGate system via the REST API.
Monitors Meraki licenses of an organization via the Cisco Meraki Dashboard API.
Monitors the free index nodes on disks of Linux/Unix and macOS systems via SSH.
Monitors the status of processes within an Orchestra scenario.

display_name: Cisco WLC Access Point Overview sensor
description: Monitors the operational status of a WLC access point and provides a sum of various network utilization metrics of the available slots.
Monitors the capacity of a virtual volume on an HPE 3PAR storage system.
Monitors the network traffic and the status of rules of a PRTG Data Hub instance.
Monitors the status of a Linux system. PRTG automatically creates this sensor on the multi-platform probe to monitor the system that the remote probe runs on.
Monitors the connectivity between a system running Linux/macOS and another device using ICMP echo requests ("ping") and SSH.
Monitors the load average of a Linux/Unix system using SSH.
Monitors the status and various statistics of a PRTG Data Hub instance.
Monitors the memory usage of a Linux/Unix system using SSH.
Monitors physical disks of a NetApp storage system via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.9.
Monitors the status of a UPS via SNMP.
Queries a JSON or an XML REST API endpoint and maps the JSON or XML result to sensor values.
Monitors an SMB or a CIFS network share.
Sends an ICMP echo request ("ping") from the probe system to the parent device to monitor its availability.
Runs a Python script (.py) on the probe system.
Monitors the free disk space on a logical disk via the SNMP. The sensor uses HOST-RESOURCES-V2-MIB::hrStorageTable.
Monitors the health of a node of a NetApp storage cluster via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.6.
Monitors SnapMirror relationships of an ONTAP storage system the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.6.
Monitors a network service by connecting to one or more of its TCP/IP ports.

display_name: SNMP Rittal CMC III Hardware Status sensor
description: Monitors the overall status of Rittal data center hardware, for example CMC III processing units, PDUs, or Rittal IoT Interfaces and the hardware status of every attached external sensor via SNMP.
Monitors the virtual disk of a Redfish-capable server.
Monitors a single parameter that is returned by a specific OID or ASN.1 MIB via SNMP.
Monitors a folder of a Microsoft 365 mailbox via Microsoft Graph.
Monitors a network interface card (NIC) of a NetApp storage system via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.10.
Monitors the state of the connection between the PRTG core and multi-platform probes.
Monitors the status of a NetApp storage aggregate via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.6.
Monitors the performance of an AWS EBS volume by reading its data from Amazon CloudWatch via the AWS API.
Monitors a logical interface (LIF) of a NetApp storage system via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.10.
Monitors the logical unit number (LUN) of a NetApp storage system via the REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.6.
Monitors the health of the PRTG application server and checks various parameters that can affect the quality of the monitoring results.
Monitors the system health of a Fortinet FortiGate firewall via the REST API.
Monitors input and output operations of a NetApp storage system via REST API using ONTAP as of version 9.11.
Monitors a web server using HTTP.
Monitors a drive enclosure of an HPE 3PAR storage system.
Monitors the performance of an AWS EC2 instance by reading its data from Amazon CloudWatch via the AWS API.
Monitors the performance of a AWS RDS database by reading its data from Amazon CloudWatch via the AWS API.
Monitors a local folder on a probe system.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors the performance of an AWS ELB load balancer by reading its data from Amazon CloudWatch via the AWS API.
Monitors the system health of a Beckhoff IPC via OPC UA.
Connects to a Modbus RTU server and monitors up to five returned numeric values.
Monitors the capacity of a CPG on an HPE 3PAR storage system.
Monitors the metrics of an Azure SQL Database (single database or elastic pool) in a Microsoft Azure subscription.
Monitors the storage account in a Microsoft Azure subscription.

display_name: Veeam Backup Job Status Advanced sensor
description: Monitors the status of a specific backup job that runs on the Veeam Backup Enterprise Manager.

Probe-independent sensor that monitors internal PRTG parameters. The sensor shows the status of the PRTG core server and checks various parameters of the PRTG core server that have an impact on the stability of the system.
Monitors the server status, uptime, and diagnostic information of an OPC UA server.
Monitors up to five numeric values returned by specific OPC UA node IDs.
Monitors the certificate of an OPC UA server, for example, the certificate's days to expiration or if it is self signed.

display_name: Dell EMC Unity Enclosure Health v2 sensor
description: Monitors the health of a (DAE or a physical or virtual DPE on a Dell EMC storage system via the REST API. Supports systems from the Dell EMC Unity family with Unity OE 5.x.
Monitors the status of all backup job runs on the Veeam Backup Enterprise Manager in the last 24 hours.
Monitors the cost in a Microsoft Azure subscription, for example, the current and previous period cost, the used budgets, or the most expensive service by category.
Monitors the status of a virtual machine in a Microsoft Azure subscription.
Connects to a Modbus TCP server and monitors up to five returned numeric values.

display_name: Dell EMC Unity Storage Capacity v2 sensor
description: Monitors a Dell EMC storage system via the REST API. Supports systems from the Dell EMC Unity family with Unity OE 5.x.

display_name: Dell EMC Unity Storage Pool v2 sensor
description: Monitors a storage pool on a Dell EMC storage system via the REST API. Supports systems from the Dell EMC Unity family with Unity OE 5.x.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.

display_name: Dell EMC Unity File System v2 sensor
description: Monitors a file system on a Dell EMC storage system via the REST API. Supports systems from the Dell EMC Unity family with Unity OE 5.x.
Monitors the loading time of a web server via HTTP from different locations worldwide using the PRTG Cloud. The locations are distributed among four continents around the globe.
Monitors the TCP ping times to its parent device from different locations worldwide using the PRTG Cloud. These locations are distributed among four continents around the globe.
Monitors the available capacity and the state of connected batteries of a Windows-based device via WMI.
Monitors the global status of all Zoom services.
Monitors the health of a physical disk on a Windows system via WMI.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors internal PRTG parameters. The sensor shows the status of the probe system. PRTG creates this sensor automatically. You cannot delete it.
Traces the number of hops that are needed from the probe system to the ‘IP Address/DNS Name’ defined in the sensor's parent device.
Receives and analyzes Syslog messages.
Monitors an SNTP server.
Monitors a TFTP server and checks if a certain file is available for download.
Monitors a virtual machine on a VMware host server via SOAP.
Monitors the hardware status of a VMware host server via SOAP.
Monitors hardware information of an ESXi server using WBEM.
Monitors the disk usage of a VMware datastore via SOAP.
Monitors a VMware host server via SOAP.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors a Microsoft SharePoint server via WMI.
Monitors the number of sessions on a Windows Terminal Services (Remote Desktop Services) server via WMI.
Monitors a shared resource on a Windows system via WMI.
Monitors a physical disk on a SAN via SSH. The SAN has to provide a CLI for this purpose.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors the UTC time of a target device via WMI.
Remotely connects to a Windows system via WMI and performs an ICMP echo request (‘Ping’) from this device to a specified target.
Connects to a Linux/Unix system via SSH and executes a script file located on the target system. This option is provided as part of the PRTG API.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors the system health of a SAN via SSH. The SAN has to provide a CLI for this purpose.
Monitors the security status of a Windows client computer via WMI. The sensor can monitor all security products that are controlled by Windows Security Center / Windows Action Center.
Monitors the performance of a Microsoft SQL Server via WMI.
Monitors free space on disks of a Linux/Unix system using SSH.

display_name: WMI Vital System Data v2 sensor
description: Monitors vital system parameters (CPU, thread, memory, network, pagefile) via WMI.
Monitors the free disk space on a drive, logical volume, or mount point via WMI.
Monitors various statistics on a WSUS server via WMI.
Connects to a Linux/Unix system via SSH and executes a script file located on the target system. This option is provided as part of the PRTG API.
Monitors available (free) system memory on Windows systems via WMI.
Connects to the parent device via WMI and monitors the health of IDE disk drives on the target system using S.M.A.R.T. This is built into most modern IDE hard disk drives.
Monitors a Microsoft Exchange Server 2003 or later via WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation).
Monitors the length of transport queues of a Microsoft Exchange Server 2003 or later via WMI. The sensor shows the same information as shown in Windows System Monitor ‘perfmon’.
Receives and analyzes SNMP traps.
Performs a custom string query via WMI.
Monitors the number of sent emails for a Microsoft IIS 6.0 SMTP service (Exchange 2003) via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors a specific Windows logfile via WMI.
Reads the print queue on the sensor’s parent device and returns the number of jobs in the print queue. The sensor can monitor queues for all printers that are installed locally.
Monitors the disk usage of a logical disk or mount point on a Windows system via WMI.

display_name: WMI Free Disk Space (Multi Disk) sensor
description: Monitors the free disk space of one or more drives via WMI.
Monitors a Windows process via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors the CPU load on a computer via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Reads the number of messages in a Microsoft message queue of the parent device.
Monitors the uptime of a Windows system via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors a Windows service via SNMP.
Monitors the status of Windows updates on a computer and counts the available and installed Windows updates that are either from Microsoft or from the local WSUS server.
Performs a custom query via WMI and monitors numerical values (integers and floats).
Monitors a Microsoft IIS server via WMI. The sensor can also monitor applications that use IIS, such as Microsoft SharePoint or Microsoft Reporting Services.

Monitors the SSL/TLS connectivity to the port of a device. The sensor tries to connect to the specified TCP/IP port number of a device with different SSL/TLS protocol versions and shows if a particular protocol is supported.
Monitors the certificate of a secure SSL/TLS connection.
Monitors bandwidth usage and traffic of a network interface via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors traffic on a device via SNMP. You can create the sensor on a device that provides traffic data. PRTG creates one traffic sensor for each individual port.
Queries a REST API endpoint and maps the JSON or XML result to sensor values.

display_name: SNMP Fujitsu System Health v2 sensor
description: Monitors the status of a Fujitsu PRIMERGY server via iRMC and SNMP. The sensor might also work on other Fujitsu devices that have an iRMC available like PRIMEQUEST servers, some storage systems of the ETERNUS product line, and CELSIUS workstations in racks.
Monitors the status and the performance of a Nutanix cluster via SNMP.
Monitors a Nutanix hypervisor via SNMP.
Monitors internal PRTG parameters. The sensor shows the status of the probe system.

Monitors entire business processes that involve several components. You can define one or more channels that combine monitoring results from other sensors or devices. You can create a customized sensor with channels based on data from other source sensors.

display_name: SNMP Dell PowerEdge System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of a Dell PowerEdge server via SNMP.

display_name: QoS (Quality of Service) Round Trip sensor
description: Monitors parameters regarding the quality of a network connection between two probes. This is important, for example, when using VoIP over this connection.
Monitors remote desktop services like RDP or the Terminal Services Client.
Monitors free disk space of a share (Windows/Samba) using SMB.
Monitors the connectivity to a SIP server using SIP options ‘Ping’. You can use the sensor to monitor VoIP services. The sensor sends ‘auth’ and ‘options’ requests to the SIP server.
Monitors a RADIUS server according to RFC 2865. The sensor tries to authenticate itself against the server.

display_name: SFTP Secure File Transfer Protocol sensor
description: Deprecated. Monitors FTP servers of a Linux/Unix system using FTP over SSH.
Sends a series of ICMP echo requests (‘Pings’) to the specified URI to determine the statistical jitter.

Monitors the time it takes for an email to reach a POP3 mailbox after being sent using SMTP. The sensor sends an email using the parent device (an SMTP server) and then scans a dedicated POP3 mailbox until the email comes in.
Monitors an email server using POP3.
Monitors a database on a PostgreSQL server and executes a defined query.
Monitors a mail server using SMTP and can optionally send a test email with every check.

Monitors the time it takes for an email to reach an IMAP mailbox after being sent using SMTP. The sensor sends an email using the parent device (an SMTP server) and then scans a dedicated IMAP mailbox until this email comes in.
Monitors the traffic of an IPsec VPN on a SonicWall NSA via SNMP.
Monitors a configured set of Windows performance counters. You can define your own channels. No predefined channels are available for this sensor.
Monitors the time that a device runs via SNMP.
Monitors a logical disk in a Synology NAS via SNMP.
Monitors an IIS application pool using Windows performance counters.
Monitors the system health of a Synology NAS via SNMP.
Monitors a physical disk in a Synology NAS via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE ProLiant Memory Controller sensor
description: Monitors a memory controller in an HPE server via SNMP.
Monitors the licenses for the services of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Juniper NS System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of a Juniper NetScreen device via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE BladeSystem Enclosure System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of an HPE BladeSystem device via SNMP.
Monitors various types of printers via SNMP.
Monitors health values of a SonicWall NSA via SNMP.
Monitors the memory usage of a Linux/Unix system via SNMP.
Monitors the IOPS on a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Monitors a logical disk in a QNAP NAS via SNMP.
Monitors performance counters for environmental measurements on Poseidon hardware via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE ProLiant Network Interface sensor
description: Monitors a network interface in an HPE server via SNMP.
Monitors performance counters on an HP LaserJet hardware device via SNMP.
Monitors a logical disk in a QNAP NAS via SNMP.
Monitors the I/O on disks of a Linux/Unix system via SNMP.
Monitors the memory usage of a system via SNMP.
Monitors the system health of a LenovoEMC NAS via SNMP.
Monitors the power supply and cooling of an enclosure that is part of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Monitors free space on disks of a Linux/Unix system via SNMP.
Monitors free space on disks of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Queries data from a Jacarta interSeptor Pro environmental monitoring system via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE ProLiant Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a physical disk in an HPE server via SNMP.
Monitors a physical disk in a LenovoEMC NAS via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE ProLiant System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of an HPE ProLiant server via SNMP.
Monitors the system load average of a Linux/Unix system via SNMP.
Monitors the system health of a QNAP NAS via SNMP.
Monitors the status of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Monitors the IOPS on a logical unit of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Monitors the status of an HPE BladeSystem via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP HPE ProLiant Logical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a logical disk in an HPE server via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Dell PowerEdge Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a physical disk in a Dell PowerEdge server via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Buffalo TS System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of a Buffalo TeraStation NAS via SNMP. Supported TeraStation systems are the 3000, 3010, 3020, 5000, 5010, 6000, and 7000 series.

display_name: SNMP Dell EqualLogic Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a disk in a Dell EqualLogic storage system via SNMP.
Monitors a string that a specific OID returns via SNMP. The sensor can map the string directly to a sensor status by using a defined lookup file.

display_name: SNMP Dell EqualLogic Logical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a volume of a Dell EqualLogic storage system via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Cisco UCS Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a physical disk of a Cisco UCS device via SNMP.
Monitors the system health of a Cisco device via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Cisco ASA VPN Users sensor
description: Monitors account connections to a VPN on a Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Cisco ASA VPN Connections sensor
description: Monitors the VPN connections on a Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Dell EqualLogic Member Health sensor
description: Monitors the health of an array member of a Dell EqualLogic storage system via SNMP.
Monitors the health status of a Cisco UCS blade server via SNMP.
Monitors the health status of the chassis of a Cisco UCS device via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP Cisco UCS System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of a Cisco UCS device via SNMP.
Monitors performance counters on an APC UPS device via SNMP.
Monitors network parameters using Cisco's CBQoS via SNMP. The sensor supports the classes ‘Class Map’, ‘Match Statement’, and ‘Queueing’.
Monitors the status of a server’s hardware component via SNMP.

Monitors entries from a table that is provided via SNMP. You can create one new sensor per table row. For each sensor, you can define up to ten channels. Each channel shows the value of one defined table column.
Monitors a string returned by a specific OID via SNMP. The sensor can check for keywords. If you want to set limits to the channel value, you can also extract a numeric value contained in the string.
Monitors the system load via SNMP.
Monitors numerical values returned for OIDs via SNMP.
Monitors performance counters on a Dell hardware device via SNMP. The data that you can monitor with this sensor depends on the available performance counters on the target system.
Monitors the free disk space on a logical disk via SNMP.
Monitors a single parameter that is returned by a specific OID via SNMP.
Sends an ICMP echo request (‘Ping’) from the probe system to the device it is created on to monitor the availability of a device.
Receives traffic data from an sFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.
Monitors the headers of data packets that pass a local network card using a built-in packet sniffer. You can choose from predefined channels. The sensor analyzes only header traffic.
Uses a compiled MIB file to create sensors that monitor a device via SNMP. The content of the MIB file determines which data types are available for monitoring.
Monitors traffic on a device using the RMON standard via SNMP. Depending on the data returned by your device, traffic data for each port can be displayed in different channels.
Monitors a network service by connecting to its port. The sensor tries to connect to the specified TCP/IP port number of a device and waits for the request to be accepted.
Monitors ADSL statistics of a Cisco router via SNMP.

Receives traffic data from an sFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. Only header traffic is analyzed. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.

Monitors the headers of data packets that pass a local network card using a built-in packet sniffer. You can define your own channels. There are no predefined channels for this sensor. The sensor analyzes only header traffic.

display_name: SNMP Cisco ASA VPN Traffic sensor
description: Monitors the traffic of an IPsec VPN connection on a Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance via SNMP.
Monitors a network card of a NetApp storage system via SNMP.
Monitors a network service by connecting to various TCP/IP ports. The sensor tries to connect to the specified TCP/IP port numbers of a device in succession and waits for each request to be accepted.
Subscribes to an MQTT topic and monitors up to five numerical values from the received JSON data.
Monitors the logical unit number of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors received messages and received payloads of an MQTT topic.
Monitors logical interfaces of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP cluster accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors volumes on a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors the network interface card of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP cluster accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors SnapMirror relationships of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors the detailed status of all services of a Microsoft 365 subscription.
Monitors the availability of an MQTT broker (server), connects to the broker as a publishing and subscribing client, and sends the data packets using a predefined topic.

display_name: HTTP IoT Push Data Advanced sensor
description: Displays data from messages that are received from IoT-capable devices (for example Sigfox devices) and that are pushed via an HTTPS request to PRTG. The sensor provides a URL that you can use to push messages to the probe system via HTTPS (secured with TLS 1.2).
Monitors the overall status of all services of a Microsoft 365 subscription.

Runs an executable file (.exe, .dll) or a script (batch file, VBScript, PowerShell) on the probe system. This option is provided as part of the PRTG API. The return value of this sensor must be valid XML or JSON.
Monitors a Microsoft personal OneDrive account using the OneDrive API and OAuth2.
Runs an executable file (.exe, .dll) or a script (batch file, VBScript, PowerShell) on the probe system. This option is provided as part of the PRTG API.
Monitors the health of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors input and output operations of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Checks a text file (for example logfiles) for certain strings.
Monitors a folder using SMB. You can monitor file changes and file ages.
Monitors disks of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage system accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors directory services using LDAP. The sensor connects to the server by trying a ‘bind’. If the server does not respond or the authentication fails, the sensor shows a ‘Down’ status.
Monitors a file located on the local disk on the probe system, parent device, or a file that is accessible via SMB. You can monitor changes to the file content and file time stamp.
Monitors the status of a NetApp cDOT or ONTAP storage aggregate accessing the API via SOAP.
Monitors the status of a system via IPMI.
Logs in to an FTP server and can monitor changes to files.
Monitors file servers using FTP and FTPS.
Monitors a database on an Oracle server and executes a defined query.
Monitors an email server using IMAP.
Checks if the IP address of the sensor’s parent device is listed on specific blacklist servers.
Monitors backups of an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors a virtual machine running on a Microsoft Hyper-V host server via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors a virtual storage device running on a Microsoft Hyper-V host server via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors mailboxes of an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors a tablespace on an Oracle server.
Monitors a database on a MySQL server and executes a defined query.
Monitors the number of items in the outgoing mail queue of an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors a database on a Microsoft SQL server and executes a defined query.
Monitors virtual network adapters running on a Microsoft Hyper-V host server via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors the DAG status of a database on an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors the public folders and subfolders of an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors database information of an Exchange server using Remote PowerShell.
Monitors a Microsoft Hyper-V host server via WMI or Windows performance counters.
Monitors the status of a Docker container.

display_name: Hyper-V Cluster Shared Volume Disk Free sensor
description: Monitors a Microsoft Hyper-V cluster shared volume via PowerShell.
Monitors an HPE Storage EVA using the sssu.exe from the HPE P6000 Command Software (previously known as HP Command View EVA Software).
Monitors Event Log entries using the Windows API.

Counts received messages that are pushed via an HTTP request to PRTG. The sensor provides a URL that you can use to push messages to the probe system via HTTP (either secured with TLS 1.2 or not secure).
Monitors the activity of an Apache web server using ‘mod_status’ over HTTP.

Displays numerical values from received messages that are pushed via an HTTP request to PRTG. The sensor provides a URL that you can use to push messages to the probe system via HTTP (either secured with TLS 1.2 or not secure).

Monitors the full download time of a web page including assets such as images. In the background, the sensor opens the web page in a browser instance to perform the measurement. Links are not followed.
Monitors the source code of a web page using HTTP. The sensor supports authentication, content checks, and other advanced parameters.
Monitors an interactive website, such as a web shop, by performing a transaction using a set of HTTP URLs. The sensor monitors whether logins or shopping carts work properly.
Retrieves an .xml file from a URL and parses it.

Displays data from received messages that are pushed via an HTTP request to PRTG. The sensor provides a URL that you can use to push messages to the probe system via HTTP (either secured with TLS 1.2 or not secure).
Monitors performance statistics of an Apache web server using ‘mod_status’ over HTTP.
Accesses a web server and retrieves XML-encoded or JSON-encoded data.
Monitors a numerical value returned by an HTTP request. In the returned HTML page, each value must be placed between brackets [ ].
Receives traffic data from a jFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.

Receives traffic data from a NetFlow v9 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. With this custom sensor, you can define your own channel definitions to divide traffic into different channels.
Receives traffic data from a jFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. With this custom sensor, you can define your own channel definitions to divide traffic into different channels.
Receives traffic data from a NetFlow v9 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.
Receives traffic data from an IPFIX-compatible device and shows traffic by type. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.
Receives traffic data from a NetFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. Several filter options are available to divide traffic into different channels.
Receives traffic data from an IPFIX-compatible device and shows the traffic by type. With this custom sensor, you can define your own channel definitions to divide traffic into different channels.
Monitors a web server using HTTP. This is the easiest way to monitor if a website (or a specific website element) is reachable.

Receives traffic data from a NetFlow v5 compatible device and shows the traffic by type. With this custom sensor, you can define your own channel definitions to divide traffic into different channels.

display_name: Dell EMC Unity Storage LUN v2 sensor
description: Monitors a logical unit number on a Dell EMC storage system via the REST API. Supports systems from the Dell EMC Unity family with Unity OE 5.x.

Monitors the availability of DICOM-capable systems and devices by sending C-ECHO requests to the target system. You can use the sensor to verify that the DICOM handshake is executed and that your target system is capable of answering DICOM messages.
Monitors the C-FIND capability of DICOM-capable systems and devices. The sensor sends a C-FIND request or MWL query to the target device and counts all found items.
Monitors the availability of HL7 interfaces. The sensor sends an HL7 message to the target device and checks for a valid response.
Monitors a DNS server, resolves domain name records, and compares them to a filter.
Monitors the costs of an AWS account by reading its data from the AWS Cost Explorer API.
Monitors the health of a cluster and indicates the system health status of PRTG itself.
Monitors internal PRTG parameters. The sensor shows the status of the PRTG core server.

Gives you a summarized status of entire business processes while monitoring several process components. You can create a customized sensor with channels based on data from other source sensors that are specific to your network.

display_name: Dell PowerVault MDi Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a physical disk on a Dell PowerVault MD3000i, MD3420, MD3620i, MD3000f, or MD3620f. The sensor might work with other models, too.
Monitors VoIP network parameters using IP SLAs from Cisco via SNMP.
Monitors a database using an ADO connection and executes an SQL query. The sensor can monitor any data source that is available via OLE DB or ODBC.

display_name: Dell PowerVault MDi Logical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a virtual disk on a Dell PowerVault MD3000i, MD3420, MD3620i, MD3000f, MD3620f, or MD3820i. The sensor might work with other models, too.
Monitors a Xen host server via HTTP.
Monitors a virtual machine on a Xen server via HTTP.
Checks a Windows domain controller for replication errors.
Deprecated. Monitors the availability of several SaaS providers.
Monitors the TCP ping times to the sensor’s parent device from different locations worldwide using the PRTG Cloud. These locations are distributed among five continents around the globe.
Monitors the loading time of a web server via HTTP from different locations worldwide using the PRTG Cloud. The locations are distributed among five continents around the globe.
Monitors the bandwidth usage of a C-STORE request to a DICOM-capable device. You can use the sensor to test your PACS, for example.
Monitors a DHCP server. The sensor sends a broadcast message to the network and waits for a DHCP server to respond.

display_name: SNMP IBM System X System Health sensor
description: Monitors the system health of an IBM device via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP IBM System X Physical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a physical disk in an IBM server via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP IBM System X Logical Disk sensor
description: Monitors a logical disk in an IBM server via SNMP.

display_name: SNMP IBM System X Physical Memory sensor
description: Monitors the memory modules in an IBM server via SNMP.
